fields.description:
I would like a way to configure Crucible to *filter out* certain kinds of files, by wildcard file name, when a Change Set is selected for review.

Our projects contain files that get updated, but do not need to be reviewed. Namely, generated code and project files. For example I would like to always filter out, *.sln, *.csproj, *.dbml, *.Designer.cs (but not *.cs). Of course, this filter list would be user configurable either at the "system level" for those of us using the download version or at the project level. If specified at both levels, then the filters would be accumulative (unless a better mechanism can be thought of).

Related posting: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/51218/how-to-filter-out-files-for-review-when-selecting-a-change-set
fields.summary: Project level file filters

fields.description: I am able to export Crucible code reviews as a pdf but the pdf only contains the comments made and refers to specific line numbers. I would like to export the code it is referring to (i.e. some snippet of before/after lines) in order to provide context for the developer who receives the pdf document. If the developer changes the code as a result of a comment in the code review and the line numbers change, then the line number references are of no use anymore
fields.summary: export Crucible review that includes source code

fields.description:
Here are the steps that I took:

# Opened a browser and navigated to our FishEye/Crucible server => Dashboard is displayed
# Clicked "Reviews" item displayed in top level menu => Review Dashboard is displayed
# Expanded "Custom Filter" item displayed in left hand frame => Custom Filter settings are displayed
# Selected appropriate project from the displayed Project drop down list
# Checked the "Draft", "Pending Approval", "Under Review", "Summarize", "Rejected", "Needs Fixing" and "Open" state checkboxes
# Clicked the "Apply Filter" button => The first page of matching code reviews is displayed
# Clicked the "2" button shown above the displayed page of matching code reviews to view the second page => A different page of code review is displayed, but not the second page
# Verified the "Custom Filter" settings => Noted that the settings had been modified, all state checkboxes except for the "Draft" checkbox have been cleared. The modified settings reflect those needed to generate the list of code reviews now displayed

I was able to reproduce it, so the first filter says that it could find 59 reviews (in my instance) when I click on the page "2" it only shows 2, only draft is marked and the pages disappears.

Thank you in advance.

Cheers,
*Douglas Fabretti*
*Atlassian Support*
fields.summary: Crucible custom filter modified when attempting to view second page of custom filter results

fields.description: Whenever I click 'edit' on a comment in Crucible, the 'Defect' checkbox is enabled. When I then post the edited comment (still with the 'Defect' checkbox enabled), the comment is not flagged as a defect.
fields.summary: Defect checkbox is enabled when I edit a comment

fields.description: If a project has many moderated reviews, then it's useful to load balance the reviews within a group of moderators. It should also be possible to set this group as default reviewer for the project
fields.summary: Allow setting a group as moderator of a review

fields.description:
We have a customer that has this patch segment in a patch file:

{code}
Index: utf8
===================================================================
--- utf8	(revision 0)
+++ utf8	(working copy)

Property changes on: utf8
___________________________________________________________________
Added: bugtraq:label
## -0,0 +1 ##
+Issue ID
\ No newline at end of property
Added: bugtraq:url
## -0,0 +1 ##
+http://www.customer.com/blah/hello.php?helpid=%HELPID%
\ No newline at end of property
Added: bugtraq:message
## -0,0 +1 ##
+Issue: %BUGID%
\ No newline at end of property
Added: bugtraq:warnifnoissue
## -0,0 +1 ##
+true
\ No newline at end of property
Added: bugtraq:logregex
## -0,0 +1,2 ##
+[Ii]ssues?:?(\s*(,|and)?\s*#\d+)+
+(\d+)
\ No newline at end of property
{code}

Crucible fails to load this patch because it is not a standard hunk. JPatch fails on it too but it should give a warning instead. We should ignore/remove all of these from pre-commit patches in the short term and maybe show the permissions changes in the long term.

This issue is exactly the same as this one: http://code.google.com/p/reviewboard/issues/detail?id=2359 

*Workaround*

Using SVN 1.8+, create the diff with the {{--patch-compatible}} flag:
{code}svn --patch-compatible diff > patch.txt{code}
fields.summary: Pre-commit review error: SVN patch containing Property changes cannot be uploaded.

fields.description:
Hi tehre.

We have been using Crucible for sometime now and we are starting to face some issue i'd like to see addressed. The issue is that when different teams are coding in different SVN branches they do all of their code reviews on those branches so we get good management reporting about the code review coverage of those branches. But when the teams merge their code to Trunk, the code review history is lost, and if you look at the code review coverage for trunk it does not depict the true picture. This is becoming critical for our setup, without the reporting on trunk management gets little value out of this setup.

Steps to Reproduce:
# Configure the Repo in Fisheye.
# Commit a file into a Branch.
# Create a review with the file included.
# Review it and close it.
# Check the Review Coverage Report of the Branch
# Merge the file into Trunk.
# Check the Review Coverage Report of the Trunk.

The Reviewed status of the file on Branch is not imported to the Trunk.

!Branches.jpg|thumbnail! !trunk.jpg|thumbnail!

Thank you in advance.

Cheers,
*Douglas Fabretti*
*Atlassian Support*
fields.summary: Importing review history after SVN merge
Add option to expand context to show entire method

fields.description:
Hi there.

In Crucible you have the following text under the user profile settings "Reviews" screen:

"Uncomplete review if defect is raised" and 
"Uncomplete review if revision is added"

"Uncomplete" is NOT a word in the English language. You have used correct grammar in the user guide:

"Set review to incomplete if defect is raised" and
"Set review to incomplete if revision is added"

It would be good if you updated the text in the application (would also make the two match).

*PS:* If you are British/Canadian the authoritative dictionary is the Oxford English Dictionary and I believe it is Merriam-Webster's for Americans.

Thank you in advance.

Cheers,
*Douglas Fabretti*
*Atlassian Support*
fields.summary: "Uncomplete" is not a word

fields.description: When opening the user initial page, FeCru checks for updates in each repository that the user has access to. This can take many many seconds if the user can see tens or hundreds of repos.
fields.summary: Initial page after login takes many seconds to load because of Recent Activity check for each repo

fields.description:
I searched for a similar issue but could not find one. So if this is a duplicate, then my apologies.

I think comments made on code reviews should have the basic ability to have a "like" ability or a voting ability (similar to the answers.atlassian.com page) where if a reviewer makes a comment about a change they wish to see, then other reviewers can "+1" that comment if they agree with it, or "-1" if they don't agree.

I think that this would easily allow the author of the code change to see what the other reviewers regard as important much easier than sifting through a bunch of comments.
fields.summary: Crucible comment like/dislike

fields.description:
When viewing large files - Fisheye loads the files in frames, so its hard to find a line within the file.
It should be possible to search for a line within a file in annotated view.
fields.summary: Search a file in annotated view

fields.description:
How to reproduce:
1. Open a review with many files (ie. 20 files)
2. Start navigating thru the list of files using the the next (".") and previous (",") short cuts. 
3. Go back and forth from the beggining to the end of the list 3 times. 
4. The crash will happen shortly.

The issue also happen when using the forward/backward links (arrows).

Issue reproduced by Atlassian Support.

See screen shot
fields.summary: Chrome crashes if during a code review the user navigate using the shortcuts

fields.description:
Nowadays, you need to add reviewers one by one into a review.

It would be awesome if Crucible allowed using mail aliases instead of individually listing specific reviewers.

Let's say 10 users from a department are responsible for a code review.
Instead of adding these 10 users one by one as reviewers, using the departmental mail alias to add all of them at once would be much easier and practical.
fields.summary: Allow sharing reviews using emails or account

fields.description:
Currently a mouse click on the source code of a file being diffed is interpreted as a request to add a comment, and Crucible opens a comment box.

It would be useful to be able to click on the source code to select the text, and click on the file line number or something like that in the window to post a comment.
fields.summary: Allow selecting source code text when diffing file versions

fields.description:
Three of the Fisheye/Crucible gadgets are automatically added to JIRA Gadget Directory, when you create an application link between JIRA and Fisheye. That is "Crucible Charts", "FishEye Charts" and "FishEye Recent Changesets". They work perfectly. 
Four other available Crucible Gadgets, i have to add manually to JIRA, via "Add Gadget to Directory" function. These gadgets are "To Do Gadget", "Hassle Gadget", "Overdue Reviews Gadget" and "Review Coverage".
The problem arises, if due to network constraints, domain for communication between Fisheye and JIRA differs from the domain that has to be used for connecting via browser.
Let's say Fisheye's internal network domain is fisheye.exampledmz.com and JIRA's is jira.exampledmz.com. The domain to be used to open UI via browser is fisheye.example.com and jira.example.com.
When i want to add e.g. hassle plugin via "Add Gadget to Directory" function, i have to use "http://fisheye.exampledmz.com/rest/gadgets/1.0/g/com.atlassian.fecru.fecru-gadgets-plugin:overdueReviews/gadgets/hassle.xml" to successfully add the gadget to the directory. If i now add this gadget to the dashboard, it is empty, because all of the http requests which are started by it, are directed to domain "http://fisheye.exampledmz.com" instead of "http://fisheye.example.com", which is configured as "site url" in admin section of fisheye.
fields.summary: Crucible Gadgets do not work, because they are not respecting site url setting of fisheye

Correct: http://<server>/cru/CR-NEUCRUCIBLE-9#c56104

What is the configuration that needs to be updated such that the email generated via the "Tools ->Email Review" contains the correct URLs?

Thanks!

Sylvia

fields.description:
I've just tried uploading a patch created by git (using {{git show}}), but it looks like Crucible doesn't understand the prefixes in the diff properly. I had two directories at my top level called "a" and "b". Clearly, it's not stripping out the 'a/' and 'b/' prefixes added by git. 

Uploading a patch generated with the {{--no-prefix}} option makes it work, but it would be nice if Crucible could understand diffs containing a prefix too (it's fairly standard for patches to have prefixes in their filenames - this is why the {{patch}} tool has the {{-p}} option).

I originally thought this was the reason that Crucible couldn't "anchor" the patch to my repository, but looks like this was CRUC-5928 instead.
fields.summary: Crucible doesn't understand git diffs

fields.description:
Reviewer A comments, Reviewer B replies, B deletes comment, A deletes comment, A completes review — they see an error and cannot complete.
or
Reviewer A comments, Reviewer B replies with a draft comment, A deletes comment, A completes review — they see an error and cannot complete.

This can also happen when there is a draft review with a reply. I'm not sure how the UI allows that situation to occur, but a customer has seen it.

*Update on 15/Jan/15:*
* The error doesn't happen for comments on file that were deleted, but for *General Comments* only.
* With this error the reviewer is unable to *complete* the review, unless the workaround is applied.
* Other user (e.g. review's author) is still able to *close* the review (but *not to complete* it, as completing a review is an option only for reviewers).

*Workaround*
* {panel:title=(!) Database - Modifying data}
Always back up your database before performing any modification to the database. If possible, try your modifications on a test server.
{panel}
* Update the deleted comments directly in the database, so they will be back to the review.
* Stop Crucible before applying any changes to the database, and make sure that you have a database backup.
* Use the following SQL command to retrieve the comments affected by this problem:
{code:sql}
select * from cru_comment c
where cru_deleted = true and exists(
  select * from cru_comment b where c.cru_comment_id = b.cru_reply_to_comment_id)
{code}
* Update the comments by "restoring them" (setting the deleted flag to false):
{code:sql}
update cru_comment set cru_deleted = false 
  where cru_comment_id in (<cru_comment_ids>); 
{code}
Where <cru_comment_ids> is the list of the ids returned by the first SQL command.

fields.description:
Crucible interface shows 2 Closed options. How are users suppose to know which one to check? Today they look at the URL (very inconvenient).

# Navigate to the Crucible Review Dashboard
# Enter a Project under the "Custom Filter" section that has known number of closed reviews, click "Apply Filter".
# Note that there are 2 "Closed" options that could be selected.
# Click each of these options and note the URL for each. One shows state=Closed at the end of the URL, the other shows state=Closed=Snippet at the end of the URL.
# Note that the returned results are different.

The one that shows state=Closed in the URL retrieves closed reviews
The one that shows state=Closed+Snippet in the URL retrieves closed snippets, which is different from reviews.

We are requesting that the interface be updated to reference the appropriate case. Rename both options to include the case, Closed Reviews and Closed Snippets or just rename one to tell them apart.

Thank you in advance.

Cheers,
*Douglas Fabretti*
*Atlassian Support*
fields.summary: Crucible Custom Filter displays 2 "Closed" options

fields.description:
Without a precise XML tag description for APIs that demand POST, it may be almost impossible to use some of them.

A good example is the:
{code}
/rest-service/reviews-v1/{id}/patch
{code}
http://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/crucible.html#d2e821

It demands POST and therefore, input thru XML. However, it just describes the URL parameter (id). 

We need a precise descriptions for each of the XML tags:
{code}
...
<anchor>
    <anchorPath>/</anchorPath>
    <anchorRepository>REPO</anchorRepository>
    <stripCount>2</stripCount>
</anchor>
...

Also, the API doc does not mention the fact that the XML must be scaped.
{code}
fields.summary: FeCru REST API docs don't provide description of the XML tags.

fields.description:
Under Settings > Reviews > Review Notifications Events, the meaning of "Uncomplete review if defect is raised" and "Uncomplete review if revision is added" can be understood in multiple ways and its location suggests that it means the wrong thing.

For example, say I create a review and after everyone completes the review I can add more revisions to the review. This uncompletes their reviews and I get a notification that they have uncompleted their reviews. In this context, I would understand "Uncomplete review if revision is added" to mean the notification that I received that tells me my reviewers have uncompleted their reviews as a result of my added revisions.

It is unexpected to me that these settings would control whether I as a reviewer should automatically uncomplete my review when someone adds revisions to the code review because the settings are located in a section titled "Review Notifications Events" and all the other settings in this section relate to when I should receive notifications.
fields.summary: Display "Uncomplete review if..." settings in separate section than notification settings

fields.description:
Specifically, ensure events are fired after a transaction has been successfully committed.
This ensures:
* Listeners will have no chance of preventing a commit during the handling of an event
* A Listener will always see data that has been successfully committed

The current pattern in Crucible is to fire the event, and then commit the transaction.

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

1) Locate some file, go to Source tab, click Create review
2) On the opened pop up screen, click Abandon review

Crucible now redirects me to http://myhostname/cru/home ("myhostname" being what's configured as "proxy-host" in config.xml) instead of the real URL ("site-url" I believe in config.xml).
fields.summary: Abandon review redirects me to http://hostname, not http://mydomain.com

fields.description:
Currently the com.atlassian.crucible.spi.services.SearchService provides a method to pass a custom filter to search reviews.
The Criteria (CustomFilterData) does not include "last updated" date.

My use case is to query Crucible with the Project and Last updated date and get the Reviews that are updated after that time.

Is there a way to accomplish this using the plugin API?
fields.summary: Add last updated date to the CustomFilterCriteria in the review search JAVA API

fields.description:
When performing a diff on a new file, I do not get any differences.  It looks like the file has not changed at all, but in reality the entire file content is new.

A traditional diff tool would show all lines as new in that case.  I think Crucible should do the same.  That way, we could also comment on lines in the new file.
fields.summary: No diff shown for new files

fields.description:
Crucible is doing a great job presenting the diffs.  However, sometimes it is really necessary to launch an external diff to be able to perform a complex code review.  E.g. if a lot of code has been moved around, I will want to launch gvimdiff and move the code around manually until I see only the meaningful differences.

If Crucible has a quick link to launch external diff tool on the currently viewed file revisions, it would be extremely helpful.
fields.summary: External diff tool

fields.description:
Crucible sometimes redirects to my hostname rather to the configured URL. E.g., my Crucible URL is code.agilio.cz but it sometimes redirects to something like http://agilio-dev/plugins/servlet/applinks/listApplicationLinks which is a host name, not the correct base URL.

It happened to me more times but can't list all of the occasions off top of my head.
fields.summary: Crucible sometimes redirects to my host name instead of the configured URL

fields.description:
The review blockers report is currently very heavy weight (read: S L O W).

To retrieve a list of users, and how many reviews they have either To Complete or To Summarize, the plugin uses an API which loads:
* all reviews in a specified state
* then for each review, it will load:
** all file revisions in that review
** all comments of that review
** all review stats etc etc

The above should be optimized to use an api (possibly new?) which is lighter weight and retrieves less data for the Review Blockers Report.

The data needed for the review blockers report is:
||User || To Complete || To Summarize ||

Essentially, for each crucible user count all reviews they currently have To Complete or To Summarize. Sort these by total number of reviews in both states. 

Before doing anything, we should profile the existing report rendering and determine where the most time is in fact being spent.
fields.summary: Improve performance of the Review Blockers Report plugin

Douglas Fabretti

fields.description:
Currently a reviewer can be transitioned back to "incomplete" on a review when:

1. a defect is raised on the review
2. a revision is added to the review

Customer would like these preferences expanded to allow the transition back to incomplete for any comment, and/or any reply

https://support.atlassian.com/browse/FSH-7988
fields.summary: Allow moderators to uncomplete completed reviews

fields.description:
Working in a corporate environment, numbers are a big deal. 
One initiative we are looking to push is code review coverage, and we would like to be able to have metrics to track our performance. 

On the surface, the "Review Coverage" Report seemed like a great fit. When we started using it, however, we realized it had problems. Work done in branches is tracked against the main metric. 

Ideally we'd like two things:
* Be able to specify particular patterns to ignore
* Be able to ignore specific filetypes (XML)

This would greatly increase the value of this tool for us.
fields.summary: Filter "Review Coverage" Report, exclude files patterns or filetypes

fields.description: Hello, I work for Cerner and we have a request from an associate to close out over 900 reviews. I logged CRC-3534 and they told me to log this JIRA so the development team is aware of this request.

fields.description:
If a Perforce depot root is moved to a new path, the existing reviews referring the old locations will show an error/exception box on Crucible UI when a user tries to open the file diffs.

Fisheye should allow the file to continue being referred (in the old location) and handle the situation without errors/exceptions being displayed to the user.
fields.summary: Handle gracefuly the situation when a Perforce trunk was moved, but a review is still referencing the old location

fields.description:
When adding content, click the "Earlier Changesets" link and then click "Later Changesets". All of the listed changesets are now in chronological order instead of reverse chronological order, with the most recent changeset at the bottom.

Additionally, the "Later Changesets" link remains enabled. Clicking it does not re-reverse the order (it remains chronological), but each click removes the top entry from the list.

If you click the "Earlier Changesets" link instead, it does not take you to the earlier changesets--instead it displays the same changesets but once again sorted in reverse chronological order with the newest changeset removed (clicking "Later Changesets" will display just the newest changeset).
fields.summary: When adding content to a Crucible review, going to earlier changesets and then returning to later changesets reverses the sort order

fields.description:
Client:

{quote}When I click on a red "x" to remove a file from a review, I get an error.

I had created a review, and added files, but then had to create a new repo. I can add files in the new repo, but can't remove the corresponding files from the obsolete repo.{quote}

I was able to reproduce the problem following these steps:
# Created a review.
# Browse Changesets.
# Chose a change of the repository.
# Done.
# Deleted the repository.
# Click on the review I just created.
# Pressed on the red [x].

This is the issue that the client opened: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/CRC-3507

I attached a printscreen of the error.

Thank you,
Douglas Fabretti
Atlassian Support.
fields.summary: Can't remove files from a review after its repository was deleted

fields.description:
If you have multiple committers mapped to you in a repository, you only see commits from one of them by default when adding content to a review.

For example, I made 2 commits recently from a wrong committer string (home email vs work). So I mapped that to my username.  Now whenever I go to add content to a review, I only see those two commits.  Not the newer ones from my main committer email.

I manually have to switch to the other committer each time.
fields.summary: Multiple committer mappings for a user has bad UX when adding content to reviews

fields.description:
It would make things a lot easier if Crucible/Fisheye moved their repository configuration from the config.xml file into the actual database.

This would leave the config.xml file only have essential startup info, such as username/password for the database.

This would allow automation systems such as Puppet to track the contents of the config.xml file and not have it change when the Crucible binary decides to write to the config file.
fields.summary: Move repository configuration from config.xml into the Database.

fields.description: In our case, add more than one default moderator for one Crucible project is needed.
fields.summary: Add Multiple Default Moderator for Crucible Project

fields.description: We have the requirement that more than one default moderator can be added to one Crucible project.
fields.summary: More than one default moderator can be added to one Crucible project

fields.description:
When diff view context lines are set to full context it is very desirable to have keyboard shortcuts (and/or floating arrows) for going to the next diff or previous diff. If you start scrolling through the code (for context), it becomes difficult to get back to the diff you were looking at or move to the next diff.

Similarly, if you have a large block of new code once you scroll such that you can no longer see the beginning of the diff block, you no longer have access to the next diff/ previous diff arrows (without scrolling back to the beginning of th4e diff). This is another instance where having keyboard shortcuts (and perhaps floating arrows) woudl be useful.

In both cases having a button or arrow and keyboard shortcut for going back to the beginning of the current diff would also be useful (AFAIK, going back to the beginning of the current diff would be new functionality).
fields.summary: Need keyboard shortcuts for moving to previous, current, and next diff.

fields.description:
The application-links plugin renders a link to configure the Application Links for each project in the project list (/admin/listProjects.do):

{code}
 <web-item key="fecruAppLinksProjectCfgWebItem" section="system.admin.project.operation" weight="5" application="fecru">
        <label key="Application Links"/>
        <link>/plugins/servlet/applinks/listEntityLinks/com.atlassian.applinks.api.application.fecru.FishEyeCrucibleProjectEntityType/${helper.project.key}</link>
        <condition class="com.atlassian.applinks.core.plugin.condition.ApplicationLinksExistCondition" />
    </web-item>

{code}

helper.project unfortunately is a relative heavy call (db select, permission checks etc) and can cause the page to load very slowly when many (~70,80) projects are configured. There are joins with the user table, and potentially remote calls to crowd (on cache miss) to getAllowedReviewers for each project.

All this data is then discarded, since only the projectKey is required to render the link.


* DefaultHelper should expose the projectKey it already has as a getter.
* The application-links plugin should use this when rendering the link.
*NB* The above change would mean the application-links plugin would no longer be backward compatible with FishEye. --> Its a bundled plugin, maybe OK. --> Check with studio, the probably overwrite it.
fields.summary: Reduce number of database calls when listing projects with Application Links in admin screen.
Internal avatar on changeset comment is broken

fields.description:
This is a blocker for Studio.

The new parameter is loadUserData, and is described as:

{code}
   * @param loadUserData true if you wish to return the list of all allowed users when a project allows all users to add
     *                      reviews. If set to false, then when all users are allowed to add reviews to a project, this will make
     *                      {@link com.atlassian.crucible.spi.data.ProjectData#getAllowedReviewers()} to return an empty list.
{code}


If allowedReviewers is irrelevant to you when getting a list of all projects, 
it is highly recommended to set this value to false (default is true) due to the performance cost in getting all allowed reviewers.
fields.summary: New parameter to GET /rest-service/projects-v1 to optionally load all user data. If false, ProjectData.getAllowedReviewers will return an empty list

fields.description:
When a reviewer completes a review either ReviewerCompletedEvent or AllReviewersCompletedEvent is fired. The latter interface does expose the current reviewer. As a work-around we are casting AllReviewersCompletedEvent to AllReviewersCompletedEventImpl in order to retrieve the initiator field.

The same problem happens with AllReviewersNoLongerCompletedEvent when a reviewer uncompletes a review.
fields.summary: Plugins cannot detect completed and uncompleted reviewers reliably

fields.description:
Hi team,
I referred to http://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/crucible.html but found no possibility to get reviews in specified time frame, like "get all closed reviews from 2011-10-01 to 2011-11-01". As from your support reply there is no such possibility, but it will be great help for all API automation work.

Best Regards, Pavel
fields.summary: Implement date filter for crucible reviews

fields.description: Currently there is no reliable way for plugins to detect when a draft comment is published. Only a CommentUpdatedEvent is fired, but it doesn't contain enough information to distinct it from the case when a user updates existing comment text.
fields.summary: Allow plugins to detect when a draft comment is published

fields.description:
When performing a perforce integrate from one branch to another (or one folder to another), if the files are not "Checked Out" before the changelist is submitted, it causes a crucible review created from that changelist to not display the diffs. The files are listed in the crucible review in Orange, and a "no change" message is displayed along with "Copied" next to the file name in the diff window. 

Fisheye shows the diffs correctly. If the files are checked out before being submitted, Crucible displays the diff correctly.

EDIT:
Seems the issue is more specifically that crucible is not diffing the correct changesets, not that it just doesn't exist. If the file in perforce has a current change set of 4897, then after integration, has a changeset of 5124, crucible has a different base revision between those 2 numbers. So crucible is trying to diff 4955 and 5124, even though a revision for 4955 wasn't available for that file. When files are checked out in perforce before submitting the integration changelist, the revision numbers are correct.
fields.summary: Integration Diffs from Perforce Don't Display

fields.description:
In the Crucible diff view of the last file of the patch there is often a difference which is not part of the patch, but added by Crucible.

See diff view and attached patch.

We see this when we use pre-commit patches and use clipboard to exchange the patch between Eclipse and Crucible.
I have not see this yet for Java files, but I see this for HTML file.
fields.summary: Precommit patch adds a diff which is not in the original patch

fields.description:
Message "Automated reminder is disabled", makes the admin/author/reviewer think that the feature was manually disabled (somewhere, like in the admin console or by the Review author), when actually, it gets disabled when the date defined is "already due".

See screen shot.

Instead of "Automated reminder is disabled", we need words that make clear that the date defined in the "Due Date" was already reached/due.
fields.summary: Automatic Reminder "disabled" wording is confusing

fields.description: We should catch errors in that situation and do something more sensible with them.
fields.summary: If during review creation the content of a file revision can't be uploaded (via FishEye), that file is regarded as having no content
